title: Should You Get a Colonoscopy or Do an At-Home Test?

content: Roughly 1 in 23 men and 1 in 25 women will get colorectal cancer in their lifetime. And cases of colorectal cancer are on the rise among people younger than 55.
If colorectal cancer is caught early, it’s easier to treat – which means a lower risk of death. So it’s vital to get screened.

The most common screening tests include at-home stool tests and colonoscopy. Which one should you do? You should always talk with your doctor about what’s best for you. But in the meantime, here’s some important info to keep in mind:

The American Cancer Society (ACS) recommends that people with average risk for colorectal cancer, which starts in the recturm or colon, start getting screened at age 45. You should continue screenings through age 75 (when you can make a decision with your doctor on whether to continue) and stop at age 85.
What does it mean to be  “average risk”? According to the ACS, this includes:
bullets: No personal history of colorectal cancer or certain kinds of growths called polyps
No family history of colorectal cancer
No personal history of IBD (including ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease)
No confirmed (or suspected) hereditary colorectal cancer syndrome, such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colon cancer or HNPCC)
No personal history of radiation to the abdomen or pelvic area to treat cancer.

content: You’re considered at increased risk if you’ve had one or more family members with colon or rectal cancer, if you’ve had certain kinds of polyps, have had colon or rectal cancer, or have had radiation to your belly. If you have IBD or a genetic syndrome listed above, you’re considered high risk.
If you’re at increased or high risk, your doctor may recommend a colonoscopy over an at-home test and/or more frequent screenings.
What Is an at-Home Stool Test?

These are stool-based tests that check for signs of abnormalities. You get a kit with instructions for collecting a stool sample at home. Then you send it back, it’s analyzed, and you get results within a couple of weeks. If your test shows any signs of abnormalities, such as blood in your stool, you’ll need to get a follow-up colonoscopy.

content: The pros: There’s no prep. That means no time off of work and no prep solution to drink. It’s also noninvasive and relatively quick to do.

content_blocks.text: The pros: There’s no prep. That means no time off of work and no prep solution to drink. It’s also noninvasive and relatively quick to do.

content: The cons: They’re not foolproof. These tests detect a very high number of colon cancers but they can miss polyps and cancer in some cases. There’s also a chance of false positives. And if you opt for these tests, you’ll need to do them more frequently, perhaps every year.
These tests are generally recommended if you’re at an average risk for colorectal cancer.

For this procedure, you’re given sedation, and a long, thin tube equipped with a camera is inserted into your anus to look at your rectum and colon. If there are any abnormal areas such as polyps, they can be removed and tested.
The pros: It’s considered the gold-standard for colorectal cancer screening. And if you have a clear colonoscopy, you may not need another one for up to 10 years.

The cons: There’s prep involved, including a clear liquid diet the day before and either drinking a prep solution or taking a course of pills to fully clean out your system before the test. You’ll need someone to drive you home from the exam and will want to take it easy afterward. There’s also a very small risk for bleeding or punctures.

content: Colonoscopies are usually recommended if you have an increased or high risk for colorectal cancer, though you can opt for this test even if you’re at average risk. (It’s always smart to check with your insurance company about coverage.)
